author: @computinghub9550
text: Still usefull in 2021 but keep in mind the following: 1) You also need to add this in "settings.py": AWS_S3_REGION_NAME = 'us-east-2' # Your region name AWS_S3_SIGNATURE_VERSION = 's3v4'  2) The CORS config is now json format: [     {         "AllowedHeaders": [             "*"         ],         "AllowedMethods": [             "GET",             "POST",             "PUT"         ],         "AllowedOrigins": [             "*"         ],         "ExposeHeaders": []     } ]

author: @deutschersyrer
text: Hey, to whoever is getting an in error when trying to add the CORS configurations, it is important to know that, and I quote from AWS Website: "Important! In the new S3 console, the CORS configuration must be JSON.". Read the note here https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/cors.html So, our version of XML can be written as bucket CORS as follows:  [     {         "AllowedHeaders": [             "*"         ],         "AllowedMethods": [             "PUT",             "POST",             "DELETE"         ],         "AllowedOrigins": [             "*"         ],         "ExposeHeaders": []     } ]  EDIT: IF that didn't work, go to  the bucket permessions, disable "block public access". Then scroll down to Bucket Policy. Here we should grant read-only permissions (Source: Granting Read-Only Permission to an Anonymous User: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/example-bucket-policies.html)...  add the following (change the name of the bucket in "resource" to be the name of the bucket you created - mine is "django-project-blog-2021") and save!  {     "Version": "2012-10-17",     "Statement": [         {             "Sid": "PublicRead",             "Effect": "Allow",             "Principal": "*",             "Action": [                 "s3:GetObject",                 "s3:GetObjectVersion"             ],             "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::django-project-blog-2021/*"         }     ] }  Now, that should work!  Last but not least, thank you very much Corey. YOU ARE AWESOME.

author: @pradnyalgandhi7524
text: If you're getting an error saying - " The CORS configuration must be written in valid JSON" , refer to the AWS documentation at https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/cors.html.  The video shows inputing an XML, however, AWS now accepts only JSON input for CORS config. Try this :  [     {         "AllowedHeaders": [             "*"         ],         "AllowedMethods": [             "PUT",             "POST",             "DELETE"         ],         "AllowedOrigins": [             "*"         ],         "ExposeHeaders": []     } ]

author: @johnstewart2704
text: AWS Changed CORS Format! I have a working solution below:  AWS no longer accepts xml for CORS configuration, it must be a JSON.   You will get this error if you use Corys XML: Expected params.CORSConfiguration.CORSRules to be an Array   This solution worked for me:   [     {         "AllowedHeaders": [             "*"         ],         "AllowedMethods": [             "PUT",             "POST",             "GET"         ],         "AllowedOrigins": [             "*"         ],         "ExposeHeaders": []     } ]

author: @markcsizmadia2109
text: Hi all, I just completed this part of Corey's amazing series. Just wanted to let you know that I got the following error: "The authorization mechanism you have provided is not supported. Please use AWS4-HMAC-SHA256'". The solution was to add the following line in the settings.py file: AWS_S3_REGION_NAME = 'us-east-2'. The region has to correspond to the one shown in your AWS console (for me US East, Ohio). Hope this helped!

author: @mountaindiaryfilms620
text: For people facing  AWS4-HMAC-SHA256 error in django-storages (images not loading). Try using this values in settings.py:  if using boto3 AWS_S3_REGION_NAME = 'us-east-2' #change to your region AWS_S3_SIGNATURE_VERSION = 's3v4'  if using boto AWS_S3_HOST = 'us-east-2' #change to your region S3_USE_SIGV4 = True   Btw Corey , you are a True HERO!!. doing such an amazing job

author: @prasangsinghal262
text: On opening an image URL I was getting an error saying the signatures doesn't match. If any of you is getting the same issue, try adding the following line.. AWS_S3_ADDRESSING_STYLE = "virtual"

author: @martinnieva8484
text: In case somebody struggles to get the images loaded, it may turn out that the region name and the signature are not set properly. Make sure to add these variables into your settings.py file: AWS_S3_SIGNATURE_VERSION = 's3v4' AWS_S3_REGION_NAME = 'us-east-2' # This one may vary, in case is the wrong one the error message will tell you which region to set to, so no worries

author: @mattb4419
text: Hi Corey, I have a question specific to this. Is it possible to only allow read permission for, say, a photo that the individual user uploaded themselves? Watching this tutorial it struck me that any individual user could access any other user's photo providing they had the file extension generated by S3, simply because the entire site is authorised to access the bucket resources. Is there a way of checking for photo ownership before allowing permission to view it? Perhaps including a user ID parameter with the view request to the S3 server. I suspect this would perhaps be something handled by the Django app rather than the S3 server itself. Many thanks in advance of your reply.

author: @IterativeTheoryRocks
text: Hi.  I had some trouble with this, as I chose to use an EU (London) based Region for my storage. From what I can tell, it requires additional settings around AWS_S3_SIGNATURE_VERSION and possibly AWS_S3_REGION_NAME (though I am not sure!). There were no obvious error messages - but I was just getting a blank for the images. I tried the 'view source' to get the image URL - but pasting that directly into the browser lead to various errors around 'access denied' and 'Signature does not match' etc.  I went back in the tutorial and used the same region as Corey to create a new bucket - this time in the US West (Oregon) region - and now everything works fine!  If anyone has any insight into this - it would be appreciated.  PS> thanks for these videos - the entire series is excellent!

author: @VictorOlet
text: Thanks Corey! It's been helpful! I have been able to use Azure Storage to store my media and static files. Similar process to AWS but I already have an Azure account. Here's some resources to start out for anyone interested: https://medium.com/@DawlysD/django-using-azure-blob-storage-to-handle-static-media-assets-from-scratch-90cbbc7d56be  Make sure that your settings.py file has the below info (Some adjustments are required from the main resource file above):  STATICFILES_DIRS = [       os.path.join(BASE_DIR, '<directory that houses the static files>/static'), ]  AZURE_ACCOUNT_NAME = '<azure storage account name>' AZURE_ACCOUNT_KEY = '<azure account key for this storage account>' AZURE_CUSTOM_DOMAIN = f'{AZURE_ACCOUNT_NAME}.blob.core.windows.net' AZURE_CONTAINER = 'static"  STATIC_LOCATION = 'static' STATIC_URL = f'https://{AZURE_CUSTOM_DOMAIN}/{STATIC_LOCATION}/'  STATICFILES_STORAGE = 'storages.backends.azure_storage.AzureStorage' DEFAULT_FILE_STORAGE = 'mysite.custom_azure.AzureMediaStorage'  Correction source: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54729137/django-azure-upload-file-to-blob-storage

author: @zxubyshops4815
text: Took me long to figure out but I was able to modify the save() function to get it to work with django-storages:      def save(self, *args, **kwargs):         super().save(*args, **kwargs)         img = Image.open(self.image)         if img.height > 300 or img.width > 300:             from django.core.files.base import ContentFile             from io import BytesIO             output_size = (300, 300)             img.thumbnail(output_size)             thumb_io = BytesIO()             img.save(thumb_io, img.format)             file_name = self.image.name             self.image.save(                        file_name,                         ContentFile(                                     thumb_io.getvalue()),                         save=False)             super().save(*args, **kwargs)  This series is awesome by the way. Please do more series using this project as a base.
